parts.text: This document reveals that as early as 2014, the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) was actively engaged in developing and "tentatively trialling" specific "regression methods" to calculate Indigenous enrolment rates. This early and sustained focus on quantifying the enrolment of a particular demographic, acknowledged by Michael Roden to have undergone "many methodological changes" since, strongly supports concerns regarding government overreach. It demonstrates the AEC's departure from a neutral administrative role of simply enrolling all eligible citizens, instead highlighting a long-standing intent to actively pursue and manipulate specific demographic enrolment outcomes. This proactive, demographically-targeted approach, even in its early stages, reinforces the narrative of the AEC engaging in "social engineering" rather than adhering to its core electoral function. Furthermore, the admission of "tentative" trials and subsequent "methodological changes" underscores the questionable precision and efficacy of the AEC's data-driven initiatives, suggesting that taxpayer funds are being expended on evolving, potentially unreliable, and ultimately interventionist programs rather than efficient, universally applied electoral administration. The mention of the 2015 ANAO report indicates that these methods and their implications have been under scrutiny for years, yet the AEC persists in refining its demographic targeting.

prompt:
From a right-leaning perspective, summarize this specific document within the context of the FOI request. Emphasize its implications for market freedom, government overreach, or national interest. The overall FOI overview is: From a right-leaning perspective, the Australian Electoral Commission's 2018-2019 reforms to its Indigenous Electoral Participation Program, while ostensibly aimed at improving enrolment, raise significant concerns regarding fiscal responsibility, individual liberty, and the scope of government. The undisclosed costs for designing, testing, and implementing the new methodology, alongside expenses for "enrolment stimulation events," represent a severe lack of financial transparency and accountability for taxpayer funds. Furthermore, the reliance on cross-agency data sharing—matching Centrelink's self-identified Indigenous status with the electoral roll—creates a de facto administrative identifier, infringing on individual privacy and expanding government reach beyond its core electoral function into social engineering. This active pursuit of specific demographic enrolment rates, driven by a "Closing the Gap" mandate, deviates from the principle of limited government and highlights a move away from neutral application of electoral law, while the methodology's acknowledged "courageous assumptions" and fluctuating outcomes further question its precision and efficacy.

Document Text:

Owen Jones

From:
Sent:
To:
Subject:

Guy Lewis
Wednesday, 5 December 2018 8:43 AM
Michael Roden
RE: Parliamentary review 3 December 2018 [SEC=UNCLASSIFIED]

Yes I found it cited in the 2015 ANAO report 

Guy 

From: Michael Roden  
Sent: Wednesday, 5 December 2018 8:20 AM 
To: Guy Lewis  
Subject: RE: Parliamentary review 3 December 2018 [SEC=UNCLASSIFIED] 

Guy, I think that reflects the first cut of the Indigenous enrolment rates we tentatively trialled 4 (?) years ago, solely 
using regression methods. Many methodological changes since then, plus a general improvement in enrolment 
rates. 

Cheers 

m. 

From: Guy Lewis <Guy.Lewis@aec.gov.au>  
Sent: Tuesday, 4 December 2018 9:17 AM 
To: Michael Roden <Michael.Roden@aec.gov.au> 
Subject: FW: Parliamentary review 3 December 2018 [SEC=UNCLASSIFIED] 

Michael, are you able to shed light on the following statement by Warren Snowden (Lingiari) in parliament 
yesterday? Do you recall where this statement might have come from? 

‘in 2014 the AEC had already identified that 42 per cent of Indigenous people were not enrolled to vote.’ 

Regards 

guy 

From: Delyse Paliaga <Delyse.Paliaga@aec.gov.au>  
Sent: Tuesday, 4 December 2018 9:12 AM 
To: Guy Lewis <Guy.Lewis@aec.gov.au>; Darryl Miller <darryl.miller@aec.gov.au> 
Cc: Jaime Garrido <Jaime.Garrido@aec.gov.au>; Sarah Gowty <Sarah.Gowty@aec.gov.au>; Robyn Legg 
<Robyn.Legg@aec.gov.au> 
Subject: FW: Parliamentary review 3 December 2018 [SEC=UNCLASSIFIED] 

Hi Guy and Darryl 

Guy are you able to check the figures re enrolment that Mr Snowden quotes in his speech below? 
Darryl do you have any comments on Mr Snowdens speech. 

Delyse 

Delyse Paliaga | Director Roll Program and Community Engagement  
Roll Management & Community Engagement Branch 
Australian Electoral Commission
